articles.headline: Illegal Immigrants Are Divided Over Importance of Citizenship
articles.snippet: Congress’s efforts on immigration have foundered over naturalization for those in the United States illegally. Yet many immigrants say they would settle for less.
articles.abstract: Congress’s efforts on immigration have foundered over naturalization for those in the United States illegally. Yet many immigrants say they would settle for less.
articles.lead_paragraph: Glendy Martínez is waiting anxiously to see if Congress will ever pass legislation to allow immigrants like her, without papers, to stay in the country legally. But frankly, she says, she does not care if it will include any promise of citizenship.

articles.headline: Fed Looks for Other Ways to Aid Economy
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee wrestled at its most recent meeting with ways of supporting an economy that still needs help.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee wrestled at its most recent meeting with ways of supporting an economy that still needs help.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials, many of them reluctant to continue the Fed’s economic stimulus campaign in its current form, wrestled at their most recent meeting with other ways of supporting an economy that still needs help.

articles.headline: Pact May Extend U.S. Troops’ Stay in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry said emphatically that there was no discussion of an American apology to President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan or to his nation.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said emphatically that there was no discussion of an American apology to President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan or to his nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Wednesday that the United States and Afghanistan had finalized the wording of a bilateral security agreement that would allow for a lasting American troop presence through 2024 and set the stage for billions of dollars of international assistance to keep flowing to the government in Kabul.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: AT&T and Verizon Pressed to Detail Roles in U.S. Surveillance Efforts
articles.snippet: Shareholder resolutions are demanding more disclosure about the companies’ role in handing over customer data to the government.
articles.abstract: Shareholder resolutions are demanding more disclosure about the companies’ role in handing over customer data to the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shareholders are putting AT&T and Verizon Wireless on notice: Tell the public more about the companies’ role in government surveillance efforts or risk a ding to the bottom line.

articles.headline: Ad Takes Off Online: Less Doll, More Awl
articles.snippet: The extensive Rube Goldberg machine in a viral video ad from a start-up toy company called GoldieBlox has a simple goal: show girls they can become engineers.
articles.abstract: The extensive Rube Goldberg machine in a viral video ad from a start-up toy company called GoldieBlox has a simple goal: show girls they can become engineers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who said girls want to dress in pink and play with dolls, especially when they could be building Rube Goldberg machines instead?

articles.headline: A Smart Smoke Alarm That Keeps Its Cool
articles.snippet: The newest product offering from the company that came up with the smart thermostat combines smoke and carbon monoxide detection in a pleasing, intuitive package.
articles.abstract: The newest product offering from the company that came up with the smart thermostat combines smoke and carbon monoxide detection in a pleasing, intuitive package.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last apartment I lived in was a certifiable fire hazard. It was mostly my fault — I ripped out the smoke detector my landlord had installed because it was so sensitive that even a steamy shower would set off its earsplitting beeping.

articles.headline: Kazakhstan’s Bet on Rail
articles.snippet: The Central Asian nation began tapping its oil fields in September, using the sovereign wealth to finance its growing rail empire that serves the big Chinese and Russian markets.
articles.abstract: The Central Asian nation began tapping its oil fields in September, using the sovereign wealth to finance its growing rail empire that serves the big Chinese and Russian markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — The railroad locomotive factory here on the outskirts of the capital of Kazakhstan is one of the most modern in the world, with huge yellow overhead cranes and a work force of 1,100. An engine factory being built next door will soon make some of the world’s most fuel-efficient 12-cylinder diesel engines.

articles.headline: Active and Improvising, Kerry Is Taking On Tough Problems
articles.snippet: John Kerry may be poised to begin delivering a major goal President Obama has long sought: an agreement with Iran to curb its nuclear program.
articles.abstract: John Kerry may be poised to begin delivering a major goal President Obama has long sought: an agreement with Iran to curb its nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Kerry has made no secret of his ambitions as secretary of state. On a visit to the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem last March, he watched as two bearded patriarchs pleaded with President Obama to bring peace to the Holy Land. Clasping their hands, Mr. Kerry said, “I’m going to work as hard as I can to get it done.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Navy Was Warned of Contractor at Center of Bribery Inquiry
articles.snippet: The Navy awarded $200 million in contracts to Leonard Glenn Francis, even after several ship crews and contracting officials had filed complaints about him.
articles.abstract: The Navy awarded $200 million in contracts to Leonard Glenn Francis, even after several ship crews and contracting officials had filed complaints about him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leonard Glenn Francis, a wealthy Malaysian contractor at the heart of one of the United States Navy’s largest bribery scandals in decades, seemed to have stepped right off the set of “Casablanca.”
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: G.O.P. Maps Out Waves of Attacks Over Health Law
articles.snippet: Republican strategists say they intend to keep Democrats on their heels through a multilayered, sequenced assault on President Obama’s signature legislation.
articles.abstract: Republican strategists say they intend to keep Democrats on their heels through a multilayered, sequenced assault on President Obama’s signature legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The memo distributed to House Republicans this week was concise and blunt, listing talking points and marching orders: “Because of Obamacare, I Lost My Insurance.” “Obamacare Increases Health Care Costs.” “The Exchanges May Not Be Secure, Putting Personal Information at Risk.” “Continue Collecting Constituent Stories.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Yellen’s Fed Leadership Is an Almost-Done Deal
articles.snippet: Janet L. Yellen on Thursday moved closer toward becoming the first woman to lead the Federal Reserve Board when the Senate Banking Committee sent her nomination to the full Senate with a 14-8 vote.
articles.abstract: Janet L. Yellen on Thursday moved closer toward becoming the first woman to lead the Federal Reserve Board when the Senate Banking Committee sent her nomination to the full Senate with a 14-8 vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s campaign to encourage economic growth was bolstered on Thursday as Janet L. Yellen moved to the verge of confirmation as the next head of the Fed, and a change in Senate procedures made it easier for the White House to fill three other vacancies on the Fed’s board.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: In Landmark Vote, Senate Limits Use of the Filibuster
articles.snippet: Responding to what they view as Republicans’ obstructionism on President Obama’s cabinet and judicial nominations, Democratic lawmakers voted to eliminate use of the blocking tactic.
articles.abstract: Responding to what they view as Republicans’ obstructionism on President Obama’s cabinet and judicial nominations, Democratic lawmakers voted to eliminate use of the blocking tactic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved the most fundamental alteration of its rules in more than a generation on Thursday, ending the minority party’s ability to filibuster most presidential nominees in response to the partisan gridlock that has plagued Congress for much of the Obama administration.
